title: Wales dreams shattered as South Africa win to set up Rugby World Cup final against England
text:
South Africa edged out Wales in a scrappy Rugby World Cup semi-final (Picture: Getty)

Handre Pollard struck a late penalty as South Africa beat Wales 19-16 in Yokohama to set up a titanic Rugby World Cup final clash with England next weekend.

In stark contrast to England’s imperious 19-7 victory over New Zealand in the first semi-final, Sunday’s encounter was an ugly affair right from the off as both teams started tentatively at the International Stadium.

South Africa drew first blood as Pollard slotted over a penalty before Dan Biggar replied with a three-pointer of his own to tie the score midway through the first half.

Pollard threatened to take the game away from Wales with two further penalties, but Biggar was again on hand to reduce the deficit to just three points at the break.

De Allende burst through to score the first try of the game in the 57th minute (Picture: Getty)

Warren Gatland’s men rallied after injuries to Tomos Francis and George North in the dying moments of the first half, with Biggar’s 46th-minute penalty leveling it up as infringements and handling errors threatened to define a scrappy match.

The Springboks produced the first moment of any real quality just before the hour-mark as Damian de Allende crashed through Wales’ defence to touch down and Pollard added the extras.

Wales hit back with a try of their own as Josh Adams crossed over from close range on the left wing and Leigh Halfpenny converted to make it 16-16 with 15 minutes remaining.

As extra-time loomed, Pollard held his nerve to strike the killer blow with a challenging penalty near the left touchline and South Africa held on for victory to shatter Welsh dreams.

The result means Wales’ wait for a Rugby World Cup final continues, while the Springboks must prepare to take on England, just as Jake White’s famous side did back in 2007.

South Africa emerged triumphant 12 years ago with a 15-6 over England at the Stade de France.

Adams crossed over to set up a tense finish in Yokohama (Picture: Getty)

Speaking after the final whistle, Wales captain Alun Wyn Jones said: ‘We showed it today, stayed in the arm wrestle and stayed in it at 16-16.

‘But we piggybacked penalties and South Africa took advantage and congratulations to them.

‘Today we fell short, it wasn’t our day and I am still proud to pull this jersey on and represent all the Welsh in the stadium.’

Wales boss Gatland added: ‘We probably gave away too many penalties in our own half and that cost us dearly.

‘We never gave up and were in the arm wrestle.

‘At 16-16 it was pretty close and you’re dreaming of the three points going our way.’

description: Wales missed out on their first Rugby World Cup final as Handre Pollard struck a late penalty as South Africa won 19-16 in Yokohama to set up a titanic clash with England next weekend.
